pullRequest.body:
This finishes the proof that all derivations in a finite-dimensional Lie algebra with non-degenerate Killing form are inner derivations, a project discussed in [this thread](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/Derivations.20on.20Lie.20algebras) with @ocfnash.

---

I am particularly open to design remarks or suggestions. More specifically, here are some points of which I doubt:
- I took the liberty of introducing local notations to ease my mind,
- I stated intermediary lemmas which might be useless outside of this file,
- I left a comment in the `Killing.lean` file for a hacky coercion I could not figure my way out otherwise.

nodes.body:
@frederic-marbach Thanks for doing this. I added [a commit](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/12250/commits/3893a6c56db943c5a26ab3a8797e5771b0015fc2) because I realised that new lemma you proposed `LieIdeal.killingCompl_eq_orthogonalBilin` should be true by definition (I also renamed it to `LieIdeal.toSubmodule_killingCompl`).

I'm out of time for today so I'll have to finish reviewing tomorrow.

I thought about this PR quite a bit today and I have some remarks:

1. The local notation is great: IMHO we underuse this feature.
2. The lemmas about `ùïÄ·óÆ` are not really so desirable because ultimately you prove this is `‚ä•` (I recognise you allude to this above)
3. Some of the results are true more generally, e.g., without assuming `[LieAlgebra.IsKilling R L]` so it would be nice to extract these
4. I think it's better to have lemmas which talk about `(ad R L).range` rather than `(ad R L).idealRange` unless the statement actually needs an ideal, since it's a simpler object

With all that in mind I tried to work out what was the core result and I learned (from your code!) that seems to be that if `D` is orthogonal to `(ad R L).range` then so is `ad R L (D x)` for any `x`. So I extracted this lemma (which doesn't require the assumption `[LieAlgebra.IsKilling R L]`) and then after adding a bit of API to `LinearMap.BilinForm` things seemed to work out quite nicely. I've pushed a commit (and merged master) so that the following suggestion should work:

So here's what I suggest:
```lean
variable (R L : Type*) [Field R] [LieRing L] [LieAlgebra R L] [Module.Finite R L]

/-- A local notation for the set of (Lie) derivations on `L`. -/
local notation "ùîª" => (LieDerivation R L L)

-- /-- A local notation for the ideal range of `ad`. -/
-- local notation "ùïÄ" => LieHom.idealRange (ad R L)

-- /-- A local notation for the Killing complement of the ideal range of `ad`. -/
-- local notation "ùïÄ·óÆ" => LieIdeal.killingCompl R ùîª ùïÄ

lemma killingForm_restrict_range_ad :
    (killingForm R ùîª).restrict (ad R L).range = killingForm R (ad R L).range := by
  rw [‚Üê (ad_isIdealMorphism R L).eq, ‚Üê LieIdeal.killingForm_eq]
  rfl

variable {R L}

-- This is really the key result
lemma ad_mem_orthogonal_of_mem_orthogonal
    {D : LieDerivation R L L} (hD : D ‚àà (killingForm R ùîª).orthogonal (ad R L).range) (x : L) :
    ad R L (D x) ‚àà (killingForm R ùîª).orthogonal (ad R L).range := by
  have : (killingForm R ùîª).orthogonal (ad R L).range = (ad R L).idealRange.killingCompl := by
    simp [‚Üê (ad_isIdealMorphism R L).eq]
  rw [this] at hD ‚ä¢
  rw [‚Üê lie_der_ad_eq_ad_der]
  exact lie_mem_left _ _ (ad R L).idealRange.killingCompl _ _ hD

lemma add_mem_ker_killingForm_ad_range_of_mem_orthogonal
    {D : LieDerivation R L L} (hD : D ‚àà (killingForm R ùîª).orthogonal (ad R L).range) (x : L) :
    ad R L (D x) ‚àà (LinearMap.ker <| killingForm R (ad R L).range).map (ad R L).range.subtype := by
  rw [‚Üê killingForm_restrict_range_ad]
  exact LinearMap.BilinForm.inf_orthogonal_self_le_ker_restrict
    (LieModule.traceForm_isSymm R ùîª ùîª).isRefl ‚ü®by simp, ad_mem_orthogonal_of_mem_orthogonal hD x‚ü©

variable (R L)
variable [LieAlgebra.IsKilling R L]

@[simp] lemma ad_apply_eq_zero_iff (x : L) : ad R L x = 0 ‚Üî x = 0 := by
  refine ‚ü®fun h ‚Ü¶ ?_, fun h ‚Ü¶ by simp [h]‚ü©
  rwa [‚Üê LieHom.mem_ker, ad_ker_eq_center, LieAlgebra.center_eq_bot_of_semisimple,
    LieSubmodule.mem_bot] at h

instance instIsKilling_range_ad : LieAlgebra.IsKilling R (ad R L).range :=
  (LieEquiv.ofInjective (ad R L) (injective_ad_of_center_eq_bot <| by simp)).isKilling

lemma killingForm_restrict_range_ad_nondegenerate :
    ((killingForm R ùîª).restrict (ad R L).range).Nondegenerate :=
  killingForm_restrict_range_ad R L ‚ñ∏ LieAlgebra.IsKilling.killingForm_nondegenerate R _

lemma range_ad_eq_top : (ad R L).range = ‚ä§ := by
  rw [‚Üê LieSubalgebra.coe_to_submodule_eq_iff]
  apply LinearMap.BilinForm.eq_top_of_restrict_nondegenerate_of_orthogonal_eq_bot
    (LieModule.traceForm_isSymm R ùîª ùîª).isRefl (killingForm_restrict_range_ad_nondegenerate R L)
  refine (Submodule.eq_bot_iff _).mpr fun D hD ‚Ü¶ ext fun x ‚Ü¶ ?_
  simpa using add_mem_ker_killingForm_ad_range_of_mem_orthogonal hD x

lemma exists_eq_ad (D : ùîª) : ‚àÉ x, ad R L x = D := by
  change D ‚àà (ad R L).range
  rw [range_ad_eq_top R L]
  exact Submodule.mem_top
```
I've been too lazy to add comments or to use the local notation though both would be good.

What do you think?

I applied your suggestions, with local notations and (some) comments.

I have a few questions:
- You added `ad_apply_eq_zero_iff ` (in `Semisimple.lean`), which looks a lot like `injective_ad_of_center_eq_bot` (in `AdjointAction.lean`). Should we keep both?
- I had added `equivRangeAdOfCenterEqBot` (in `AdjointAction.lean`), but your solution does not use it anymore, should we keep it?
- Eventually, I had named the file `Semisimple.lean`, but should it be `Killing.lean`?

>     * You added `ad_apply_eq_zero_iff ` (in `Semisimple.lean`), which looks a lot like `injective_ad_of_center_eq_bot` (in `AdjointAction.lean`). Should we keep both?

Yes, we should keep both. `injective_ad_of_center_eq_bot` is useful as input to lemmas that demand this hypothesis and `ad_apply_eq_zero_iff `has several useful features: 

- It is a useful `simp` lemma
- It is useful for rewriting
- It picks up the trivial center condition via typeclasses

It could be generalised if we had a typeclass `LieAlgebra.HasTrivialCenter` (or something) but I'm not sure if we need this and anyway, that's out of scope for this PR.

>     * I had added `equivRangeAdOfCenterEqBot` (in `AdjointAction.lean`), but your solution does not use it anymore, should we keep it?

Good point, I think we should drop this now.

>     * Eventually, I had named the file `Semisimple.lean`, but should it be `Killing.lean`?

Yes, probably `Killing.lean` is a better name
Thanks. I fixed the typo, renamed the file, and removed my useless lemma.

:v: frederic-marbach can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8806249344/job/24170618879)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8806249344/job/24170619374)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8806249344/job/24170619713)

Thanks. Very nice work! Two mini comments

bors d+

Thanks for doing this, I learned the proof from your work!

I think this is ready to be merged but I'm going to ask for another reviewer to take a look because the PR now contains a mixture of your work and mine.

Thanks. Very nice work! Two mini comments

bors d+

This is actually true by definition:
```suggestion
lemma traceForm_isSymm : LinearMap.IsSymm (traceForm R L M) := LieModule.traceForm_comm R L M
```
which makes me think we should drop `traceForm_comm` and just use this new `traceForm_isSymm` everywhere instead. (Not necessary as part of these changes.)
Ok. I will prepare a dedicated commit once we merge this one.

I suggest:
```suggestion
lemma injective_ad_of_center_eq_bot (h : LieAlgebra.center R L = ‚ä•) :
    Function.Injective (ad R L) := by
  rw [‚Üê LieHom.ker_eq_bot, ad_ker_eq_center, h]

noncomputable def equivRangeAdOfCenterEqBot (h : LieAlgebra.center R L = ‚ä•) :
    L ‚âÉ‚Çó‚ÅÖR‚ÅÜ (ad R L).idealRange :=
  letI e‚ÇÅ := LieEquiv.ofInjective (ad R L) (injective_ad_of_center_eq_bot h)
  letI e‚ÇÇ := LieEquiv.ofEq (ad R L).range (ad R L).idealRange (by ext; simp [mem_ad_idealRange_iff])
  e‚ÇÅ.trans e‚ÇÇ
```
The following minor points are the reasons for my suggestion:

1. These results hold for any coefficients
2. It is likely that one day we'll want to use these for Lie algebras with trivial center that do not have non-degenerate Killing form
3. We should follow the snake / camel -case conventions of our [naming conventions](https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/naming.html#general-conventions) (even though I don't really like these)
4. You should try never to build data using tactic mode because it produces awkward terms: tactic mode is only for `Prop` (where we don't care what the term is). The `def` here is data. More importantly because you have used an opaque `have` rather than a transparent `let`, we could never prove anything about this `def` (e.g., its behaviour when applied to an element): we would know only that it exists.

1+2: OK. In fact, now that they don't depend on Killing stuff anymore, I moved both lemmas to the base `AdjointAction.lean` file.

3+4: Thank you for the explanation! Part of the issue was that I had first stated this as a `lemma`, and the CI linter told be it should be a `def` instead.

```suggestion
- `LieDerivation.Killing.range_ad_eq_top`: in a finite-dimensional Lie algebra with non-degenerate
```

```suggestion
```

```suggestion
derivations.
```

```suggestion
@[simp]
lemma range_ad_eq_top : ùïÄ = ‚ä§ := by
```
This seems like a good simp lemma to me.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(Algebra/Lie): prove derivations are inner in finite-dimensional Killing Lie algebra

nodes.body:
@frederic-marbach Thanks for doing this. I added [a commit](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/12250/commits/3893a6c56db943c5a26ab3a8797e5771b0015fc2) because I realised that new lemma you proposed `LieIdeal.killingCompl_eq_orthogonalBilin` should be true by definition (I also renamed it to `LieIdeal.toSubmodule_killingCompl`).

I'm out of time for today so I'll have to finish reviewing tomorrow.

I thought about this PR quite a bit today and I have some remarks:

1. The local notation is great: IMHO we underuse this feature.
2. The lemmas about `ùïÄ·óÆ` are not really so desirable because ultimately you prove this is `‚ä•` (I recognise you allude to this above)

4. I think it's better to have lemmas which talk about `(ad R L).range` rather than `(ad R L).idealRange` unless the statement actually needs an ideal, since it's a simpler object

With all that in mind I tried to work out what was the core result and I learned (from your code!) that seems to be that if `D` is orthogonal to `(ad R L).range` then so is `ad R L (D x)` for any `x`. So I extracted this lemma (which doesn't require the assumption `[LieAlgebra.IsKilling R L]`) and then after adding a bit of API to `LinearMap.BilinForm` things seemed to work out quite nicely. I've pushed a commit (and merged master) so that the following suggestion should work:

So here's what I suggest:
```lean
variable (R L : Type*) [Field R] [LieRing L] [LieAlgebra R L] [Module.Finite R L]

/-- A local notation for the set of (Lie) derivations on `L`. -/
local notation "ùîª" => (LieDerivation R L L)

-- /-- A local notation for the ideal range of `ad`. -/
-- local notation "ùïÄ" => LieHom.idealRange (ad R L)

-- /-- A local notation for the Killing complement of the ideal range of `ad`. -/
-- local notation "ùïÄ·óÆ" => LieIdeal.killingCompl R ùîª ùïÄ

lemma killingForm_restrict_range_ad :
    (killingForm R ùîª).restrict (ad R L).range = killingForm R (ad R L).range := by
  rw [‚Üê (ad_isIdealMorphism R L).eq, ‚Üê LieIdeal.killingForm_eq]
  rfl

variable {R L}

    ad R L (D x) ‚àà (killingForm R ùîª).orthogonal (ad R L).range := by
  have : (killingForm R ùîª).orthogonal (ad R L).range = (ad R L).idealRange.killingCompl := by
    simp [‚Üê (ad_isIdealMorphism R L).eq]
  rw [this] at hD ‚ä¢
  rw [‚Üê lie_der_ad_eq_ad_der]
  exact lie_mem_left _ _ (ad R L).idealRange.killingCompl _ _ hD

lemma add_mem_ker_killingForm_ad_range_of_mem_orthogonal
    {D : LieDerivation R L L} (hD : D ‚àà (killingForm R ùîª).orthogonal (ad R L).range) (x : L) :
    ad R L (D x) ‚àà (LinearMap.ker <| killingForm R (ad R L).range).map (ad R L).range.subtype := by
  rw [‚Üê killingForm_restrict_range_ad]
  exact LinearMap.BilinForm.inf_orthogonal_self_le_ker_restrict
    (LieModule.traceForm_isSymm R ùîª ùîª).isRefl ‚ü®by simp, ad_mem_orthogonal_of_mem_orthogonal hD x‚ü©

variable (R L)
variable [LieAlgebra.IsKilling R L]

@[simp] lemma ad_apply_eq_zero_iff (x : L) : ad R L x = 0 ‚Üî x = 0 := by
  refine ‚ü®fun h ‚Ü¶ ?_, fun h ‚Ü¶ by simp [h]‚ü©
  rwa [‚Üê LieHom.mem_ker, ad_ker_eq_center, LieAlgebra.center_eq_bot_of_semisimple,
    LieSubmodule.mem_bot] at h

instance instIsKilling_range_ad : LieAlgebra.IsKilling R (ad R L).range :=
  (LieEquiv.ofInjective (ad R L) (injective_ad_of_center_eq_bot <| by simp)).isKilling

lemma killingForm_restrict_range_ad_nondegenerate :
    ((killingForm R ùîª).restrict (ad R L).range).Nondegenerate :=
  killingForm_restrict_range_ad R L ‚ñ∏ LieAlgebra.IsKilling.killingForm_nondegenerate R _

lemma range_ad_eq_top : (ad R L).range = ‚ä§ := by
  rw [‚Üê LieSubalgebra.coe_to_submodule_eq_iff]
  apply LinearMap.BilinForm.eq_top_of_restrict_nondegenerate_of_orthogonal_eq_bot
    (LieModule.traceForm_isSymm R ùîª ùîª).isRefl (killingForm_restrict_range_ad_nondegenerate R L)
  refine (Submodule.eq_bot_iff _).mpr fun D hD ‚Ü¶ ext fun x ‚Ü¶ ?_
  simpa using add_mem_ker_killingForm_ad_range_of_mem_orthogonal hD x

lemma exists_eq_ad (D : ùîª) : ‚àÉ x, ad R L x = D := by
  change D ‚àà (ad R L).range

  exact Submodule.mem_top
```
I've been too lazy to add comments or to use the local notation though both would be good.

What do you think?

I applied your suggestions, with local notations and (some) comments.

I have a few questions:
- You added `ad_apply_eq_zero_iff ` (in `Semisimple.lean`), which looks a lot like `injective_ad_of_center_eq_bot` (in `AdjointAction.lean`). Should we keep both?
- I had added `equivRangeAdOfCenterEqBot` (in `AdjointAction.lean`), but your solution does not use it anymore, should we keep it?
- Eventually, I had named the file `Semisimple.lean`, but should it be `Killing.lean`?

- It is a useful `simp` lemma
- It is useful for rewriting
- It picks up the trivial center condition via typeclasses

It could be generalised if we had a typeclass `LieAlgebra.HasTrivialCenter` (or something) but I'm not sure if we need this and anyway, that's out of scope for this PR.

>     * I had added `equivRangeAdOfCenterEqBot` (in `AdjointAction.lean`), but your solution does not use it anymore, should we keep it?

Good point, I think we should drop this now.

>     * Eventually, I had named the file `Semisimple.lean`, but should it be `Killing.lean`?

Yes, probably `Killing.lean` is a better name

Thanks for doing this, I learned the proof from your work!

I think this is ready to be merged but I'm going to ask for another reviewer to take a look because the PR now contains a mixture of your work and mine.
Thanks. I fixed the typo, renamed the file, and removed my useless lemma.

source.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: define Lie module structure on derivations

nodes.body:
Thanks. Very nice work! Two mini comments

bors d+

:v: frederic-marbach can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.
